p: Current prevention strategies for seasonal influenza involve the use of vaccines produced either in chicken eggs or tissue culture, but the time required for their production delays any large-scale prevention effort in the event of a pandemic [ 8]. Furthermore, the overall vaccine effectiveness for all endemic influenza strains ranged in recent years from 56 to 62% [ 9– 11]. A universal vaccine, providing effective and lasting immunity against all subtypes and strains of IAV, is not yet available despite promising strategies and experimental data in animal models [ 12]. Current treatment options for influenza virus infections include two classes of antivirals, the M2-inhibitors (e.g. amantadine) and the neuraminidase inhibitors (e.g. oseltamivir). There is widespread resistance to the M2-inhibitors, and while the neuraminidase inhibitors are currently effective against most influenza strains circulating in humans [ 13], the potential for emergence of resistance exists and has already been demonstrated [ 14– 18].
